definition[0]: to become red in the face, for example when you are angry or embarrassed
example[0]: Susan flushed deeply and looked away.
example[2]: Robyn felt her cheeks flush scarlet.
definition[1]: if you flush a toilet, or if it flushes, you make water go through it to clean it
example[4]: Why do children never remember to flush the loo?
example[5]: She flushed the rest of her drink down the toilet.
definition[2]: to force water through a pipe in order to clean it
example[6]: They flush clean water through the pipes once a day.
definition[3]: a red colour that appears on your face when you are angry or embarrassed
example[7]: His words brought a warm flush to her face.
definition[4]: the part of a toilet that cleans it with a sudden flow of water
definition[5]: the act of cleaning a toilet by forcing water through it
definition[6]: a set of cards that someone has in a card game that are all of the same suit
definition[7]: if two surfaces are flush, they are at exactly the same level, so that the place where they meet is flat
example[9]: Make sure that the cupboard is flush with the wall.
definition[8]: if someone is flush, they have plenty of money to spend
example[10]: I’m feeling flush at the moment.
definition[9]: to have a lot of money at a particular time
example[11]: Singapore’s savings rate is so high that the banks are flush with funds.
example[12]: The group is flush and has been making more acquisitions.
definition[10]: to be very successful, and keen to achieve more success
example[13]: Flushed by success in selling homes in the slump, developers now plan to do the same in the commercial property sector.
example[14]: You can get a dealer who is a busted flush at 30.
